unkerpaulie

Before I start, I just want to point out the reason I put this thread in here and not in religion debates. I would like this thread to remain on topic and fairly self-moderated. Challenging religious and biblical doctrines tend to get very emotional and often hostile, especcially lately in the religion forum, myself included as guilty of attacks. I want to break away from that trend on this particular issue. I'm hereby refraining from attacks, emotional reactions and unnecessary tangent during this discussion,and I'm asking that everyone else who participates please do the same. 
 
 This thread is for the most part in response a challenge I put toward Archangel and Easyrider. Its also something I am personaly and genuinely interested in. Archangel particularly requested that arguments be based on historical, scientific and theological evidence. Since theological evidence wasn't defined by arch, I will define it as scriptural reference based on the literal english meaning on the quoted scripture. 
 
 John 14:12 "Truly, truly, I say to you, he who believes in me will also do the works that I do; and greater works than these will he do, because I go to the Father."
 
 From my experience, there are no "greater works" than what Jesus did taking place today, nor last year, nor in the last, say 200 years or even longer. The miracles that Jesus performed according to the bible were logic and science defying. They were truly supernatural. Feeding over 5000 people by miraculously multiplying the food, walking on water, speaking to the weather, restoring withered and deformed limbs to full strength and size, and so on. If anyone could possibly perform these feats or greater, there would be without doubt worldwide coverage. In fact, miraculous works should be a very common thing by now. I think christianity is still on the rise, believers are praying to God all over the world non-stop. Yet for some reason there is an undeniable lack of anything that could possibly be even in the same zone as the works that the bible said Jesus did. 
 
 So, did Jesus lie? If Jesus really did do the acts described in the gospels, and Jesus made that statement, and there are people believing in him alive today, then we should be seeing these greater works being performed. Since this is not the case, then either:
 Jesus lied when he made these statements;
 John lied by quoting statements Jesus never made; or
 Nobody in the world today believes in Jesus. 
 
 Which is it?

 From my experience, there are no "greater works" than what Jesus did taking place today, nor last year, nor in the last, say 200 years or even longer. The miracles that Jesus performed according to the bible were logic and science defying. They were truly supernatural. Feeding over 5000 people by miraculously multiplying the food, walking on water, speaking to the weather, restoring withered and deformed limbs to full strength and size, and so on. If anyone could possibly perform these feats or greater, there would be without doubt worldwide coverage. In fact, miraculous works should be a very common thing by now. I think christianity is still on the rise, believers are praying to God all over the world non-stop. Yet for some reason there is an undeniable lack of anything that could possibly be even in the same zone as the works that the bible said Jesus did. 
 
 So, did Jesus lie? If Jesus really did do the acts described in the gospels, and Jesus made that statement, and there are people believing in him alive today, then we should be seeing these greater works being performed. Since this is not the case, then either:

 Noting the bolded, I must agree that Jesus accomplished supernatural acts which nobody since has equalled. Even though we see that the Apostles commanded amazing feats in His name. If we take that verse on its own and apply it universally, what it tells me, and I can speak for myself here, human beings have the potential to do the things Jesus did, but we neither have the faith or the discipline to command the authority He makes available to us. 
 
 But in order to exercise the power and authority which Jesus possessed, it takes a well rounded spirit of discipline and commitment to the ways of God which are laid out in His hand book, the bible. We call them spiritual laws and it requires faithfully practicing these principles in our daily walk in order to really have not only the authority but the confidence to even attempt what Jesus commanded during His lifetime. Here's what I mean.
 
 But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, faithfulness, self-control (Gal. 5:22).
 
 For God has not given us a spirit of timidity, but of power and love and discipline (2 Tim. 1:7 NASB).
 
 There are many verses which when put together in practice empower us to realize these supernatural abilities. But how many human beings truly encompass these spiritual disciplines? Very few if any have ever truly reflected what jesus represented as the perfect example for us.
 
 Christian disciplines need not be looked upon as unpleasant, or as a legalistic obligation. When practiced meaningfully they become sources of strength and joy. Neither should we think of the spiritual disciplines as some dull drudgery aimed at exterminating laughter from the face of the earth. Joy is the keynote of spiritual discipline. Spiritual discipline may well be considered as a joyful response to the grace of God. 
 
 Prayer can actually become a hunger, meditation a time of resting, and reflection a time of pulling oneself together again. These are the unrealized realities which I have failed to practice in my daily walk which is why I'm not a perfect reflection of the example Jesus set for us. Even though Jesus made it very clear that we have the capability to accomplish such things. I haven't exercised the personal commitment, will or discipline to attain such spiritual accomplishments.
 
 But I have both witnessed and experienced miracles such as supernatural healings and angelic interventions. These experiences are undeniable and speak to Gods grace and faithfulness rather than my spiritual insight.

 26 And beside all this, between us and you there is a great gulf fixed: so that they which would pass from hence to you cannot; neither can they pass to us, that would come from thence.

Hi All,
 
 I'm really new to this forum. Been reading alot of the religion debates and have found them very interesting.
 
 Here is 2 cents on this topic or more over most I guess when you have 2 oposite sides bebating God,Jesus, the Bible.
 
 1. For the non believer the Bible is false, untrue, crazy
 2. for the non believer the Believer is either nuts, crazy, whatever, who cares
 3. For the believer, they should in all ways (which is really hard), do everything in love.
 
 For the non believer (I used to be one not so long ago). You want facts, proof, physical, or otherwise from some scholar that "you" trust and a valid source. 
 
 For the believer - the facts and proof are in the bible. Everything else to back up the bible as proof like, geology, archaeology, are added to the foundation of belief in the bible, jesus, etc. etc.
 
 So my point is this I guess. The bebates will never end, no 1 side will "win". 
 
 I found this in Isaiah - and for the most part, it sums up for me (and alot of christians), what we as believers are up against in a world and currupt and evil as ours.
 
 saiah 55:8-9 (New International Version)
 
 8 "For my thoughts are not your thoughts,
 neither are your ways my ways,"
 declares the LORD.
 
 9 "As the heavens are higher than the earth,
 so are my ways higher than your ways
 and my thoughts than your thoughts.
 
 I didn't believe this passage a few years ago, nor did I believe much about the bible. But, once I opened my mind up a bit and took at the closed view from our America society and the world at large with all it's really messed up problems. I Read, and read and at first I did try to take thing literally, but after time, and talking to other believers and non believers it was very apparent to me that no matter how are any of us tries to disprove, or discount either the believer or non believer the above versus just seems to sum it all up.
 
 Ok... I guess you can now pick apart my comment.... waiting.. =)
 
 ps. please excuse the typos or grammar mistakes.... thank you.

 This is truly the cause of the great divide between theists and atheists. Based on this verse (and others that are similar) christians abandon the pursuit of knowledge, because they are preconditioned to believe that they have an inferior intellect. You feel uncomfortable when asked questions that may challenge what you believe, because you don't know the answer, don't want to know the answer, and believe that you are incapable of knowing the answer. Not only that, but you combine this verse with other scriptures that talk about God being supreme, authoratative, and always right. So you feel that you already know everything you need to know, and you bluntly refuse to learn anything new. Whether you hate knowledge or fear knowledge I can't say, but you avoid knowledge at all costs. 
 
 People who end up being atheists are the ones that are open to questions. We seek new information, test it, question it, test it some more, and then build our beliefs based of knowledge that can be questioned and tested, and still prevail. We challenge old beliefs in the face of new evidence. We allow old beliefs, that we might have held closely, to die and make way for beliefs that are better supported by evidence in reality. 
 
 I cannot accept the idea that God cannot be comprehended, just because the bible that tells us about this God says so. This is a lame excuse to remain ignorant. Do you really feel that your God requires you to remain ignorant? If the bible says one thing, such as believers will do greater miracles than Jesus did in his time, then why shouldn't we look at real life to see if this is true? Isn't this how you accept everything else you read in the bible? That's all I'm doing.
